summary: The document comprises payroll authorization forms and memoranda from the U.S. House of Representatives, detailing Thomas Howarth's employment with the Select Committee on Assassinations. It outlines his various roles, salary adjustments, and the bureaucratic payroll processes, including the necessity for staff to disclose familial ties to Members of Congress. This collection is part of the Assassination Records Review Board's archives, suggesting its historical significance, possibly in relation to the JFK assassination.
key_findings: Thomas Howarth served in multiple capacities, such as Budget Officer and Deputy Staff Director, with annual salaries varying from $18,450 to $81,200.
Illustrates the procedural aspects of payroll authorization in the U.S. House of Representatives, including the role of the Committee on House Administration.
A January 3, 1977, memorandum specifies the obligation for staff to report any family connections to sitting Members of Congress during payroll certification.
This collection's inclusion in the Assassination Records Review Board's archives points to its potential relevance to historical inquiries, possibly connected to the JFK assassination.
